author: Sam Chimenti
title: chevron-right
text: NORTHSTATE, Calif. â€” The Department of Water Resources (DWR) shared their first snowpack survey of 2024 on Tuesday. Last year's snowpack was one of the largest ever in California, with a [fifth survey](https://water.ca.gov/News/News-Releases/2023/May-2023/May-2023-Snow-Survey) [last May reading as 254% above-average. But early in this new year, that number is much different.](https://water.ca.gov/News/News-Releases/2023/May-2023/May-2023-Snow-Survey) Below is the [first comparison](https://krcrtv.com/news/local/gallery/california-department-of-water-releases-first-snowpack-survey-of-2024?photo=2) between last year and this year, courtesy of the DWR. Phillips is the main survey station, near Lake Tahoe. Those numbers are on the top, with state-wide numbers on the bottom. In both cases, the yearly difference is drastic. A big change this winter is the fact we're in an [ El Nino](https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/december-2023-el-nino-update-adventure) yearâ€”the first since 2018/2019â€”which means, in simple terms, that the jet streams are switched and conditions are thrown out of whack. But El Ninos are not a perfect indicator of whatâ€™s to come during winter. The DWR says there has been extreme annual variances in recent winters. In terms of last winter, officials told KRCR it was truly an outlier. "I would definitely classify last year as an extreme anomaly," said Michael Anderson, State Climatologist for the DWR. "We really had some unusual events line up that created those windows where we had a lot of really extreme activity, and then we had these windows where absolutely nothing was happening. And this period of really wet, really dry, really wet." "What we're seeing this year more [is] not quite the strength of either wet or dry, but everything kind of being a little bit subdued," Anderson continued. Anderson and Andrew Schwartz of the [UC Berkeley Central Sierra Snow Lab](https://vcresearch.berkeley.edu/research-unit/central-sierra-snow-lab) each said it is too soon to know how the state's snow pack/water supply will look in 2024. In regards to [this week's storms](https://twitter.com/NWSSacramento/status/1742283967490048241?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet), both men said the outlook likely won't change much, although many ski parks are expected to get a needed boost. The DWR will conduct several other snowpack surveys between now and the spring, with their peak data coming in April. One early positive is that experts believe our precipitation levels across California will ultimately finish above-average. -- To report errors or issues with this article please

author: Charrvi Singh
title: Novak Djokovic Remains Doubtful Over Tennis Future in a Staggering Admission Ahead of Australian Open 2024 - EssentiallySports
text:
Novak Djokovic was spotted in Perth. The Serb was probed by the media to answer quite a few questions.
Americaâ€™s Favorite Video Today
However, one question in particular prompted the Serb to put out quite an interesting response. After all these years, itâ€™s evident that Djokovicâ€™s love for the sport is quite intact. What he said is definitely worth talking about.
The Uncertain horizon for Novak Djokovic ADVERTISEMENT
Article continues below this ad
Djokovic found himself in the hot seat, facing an array of inquiries from the media when he landed in Perth. As the questions volleyed back and forth, an intriguing query hung in the air. This cast an impending shadow over the Serbianâ€™s future down under. In response to the pivotal question about the possibility of this being his last Australian Summer, Djokovicâ€™s uncertainty unfolded in a candid dialogue.
â€œIâ€™m always happy when I return to Australia!â€ ðŸ˜Š
Novak Djokovic has landed in Perth for the start of his 2024 season at the #UnitedCup ! ðŸ† pic.twitter.com/ilDcPi4EfP
â€” Eurosport (@eurosport) December 28, 2023
The Serbian maestro subtly hinted at the unpredictability of his tennis journey, admitting to lacking a concrete plan for the upcoming year. He stated: â€œI hope itâ€™s not the last.â€ His words carry the weight of a champion contemplating an uncertain horizon.
Trending Venus Williams Turns Proud Owner as $5.2 Billion Team Makes It Big at NFL Playoffs December 26, 2023 02:37 am EDT
Year After Surprise Party for Olympia, Will Jehovahâ€™s Witness Serena Williams Replicate the Feat to Ring in the Holiday Season? December 25, 2023 06:03 pm EDT
Serena Williamsâ€™ â€˜Sweating Like Crazyâ€™ Admission Prompts Venus Williams to Doubt Herself- â€˜Mistake to Be Hustling..â€™ December 26, 2023 08:55 am EDT
Serena Williamsâ€™ Weird Gym Obsession Cracks up Her Girl Gang Involving Ciara and La La Anthony December 27, 2023 04:16 pm EDT
Serena Williams Might Speak Fluent French But She Once Rated This As The â€˜Most Beautifulâ€™ Language In The World December 26, 2023 08:13 pm EDT

Follow Us
He continued: â€œI always look forward, as I said, coming back to Australia, and you know, Iâ€™ve always felt like I played my best tennis over the years and had great support.â€ These words were well laden with sentiments. The statement offers a glimpse into Djokovicâ€™s deep connection with the Australian tennis scene. Yet, the enigma persists as Djokovic reveals his lack of a definitive blueprint for the future.
Novak Djokovicâ€™s Roger Federer-Like Transformation Chosen as His Biggest Change From Good to Great
In his words: â€œIâ€™m not sure, I donâ€™t really have a plan for whatâ€™s going to happen next year.â€ His laid-back approach, taking it â€œ season by season,â€ adds an element of suspense to the whole narrative. This invites fans and pundits alike to ponder the trajectory of one of tennisâ€™s greatest sagas.
ADVERTISEMENT
Article continues below this ad
Djokovicâ€™s rebound and Alcarazâ€™s rise This journey follows a pitstop in Riyadh, where the Serbian maestro faced a setback. Djokovic lost an exhibition match to the formidable Carlos Alcaraz . Despite the stumble, Djokovic swiftly transitioned to the practice courts. All in due time for preparation of the Australian Open.
In contrast, Alcaraz took a unique route post-Riyadh. The rising Spanish star is set to engage in a duel against fellow countryman Roberto Bautista Agut. As Djokovic readies for redemption, Alcaraz charts a course for further prominence. All of this creates an intriguing intersection of two tennis narratives on the global stage.

Article continues below this ad
As fans are waiting up for the coming season, thereâ€™s a palpable anticipation, wondering if this might be the year Djokovic decides to hang up his racket. What are your thoughts on this? Let us know in the comments.

author: @billyhallowell
title: â€˜The Greatest Miracleâ€™ at Center of Massive Revival Effort on Southern Border Where Countless Are Being Baptized, Healed â€“ Faithwire
text: A preacher who set out this month to pray over the entire southern border said his tent revivals, baptisms, and invocations are changing lives. Listen to them on the latest episode of â€œQuick Startâ€ ðŸ‘‡ Pastor Tony Suarezâ€™s [Revival on the Border](https://revivalmakers.com/revival-on-the-border/) already unfolded in El Paso, Texas, from March 21-23, and will arrive in McAllen, Texas, from March 27-29, with nightly revival meetings concluding on Good Friday. Suarez said the first wave of evangelistic outreach in El Paso was remarkable. â€œOur street evangelism team set out to reach everyone, everywhere!â€ the preacher told CBN News. â€œFrom bars to city parks to those we could get to come to the tent â€” when it was all set and done, God gave us a harvest of over 3,000 souls that had an experience with God, in some form or fashion.â€ Prayer is a vital component of the Revival on the Border effort, with Suarez explaining how a â€œprayer armyâ€ was equipped and sent out the last night of the El Paso event. These individuals then journeyed to spaces across the southern border to offer invocations, minister, and hand out resources. â€œStarting in El Paso â€” and in each city theyâ€™ve been to â€” weâ€™ve driven a stake into the ground claiming that city for the Lord,â€ he said. â€œThe prayer army was tasked with speaking the name of Jesus over every single mile of the border between Texas and Mexico, as well as praying in the Spirit, and reaching people along the way.â€ Suarez continued, â€œThese men have handed out Bibles to migrants, border patrol agents [and] they have preached in parks and ministered to people in restaurants.â€ The preacher said dozens have been baptized and experienced healing. But he added, â€œThe greatest miracle of all is people giving their lives to God!â€ Suarez asked people to continue praying for those encountering these revival events through March 29. Find out more about Revival on the Border [here](https://revivalmakers.com/revival-on-the-border/). ***As the number of voices facing big-tech censorship continues to grow, please sign up for [Faithwireâ€™s daily newsletter](https://www.faithwire.com/newsletter/) and download the [CBN News app](https://www1.cbn.com/cbn-apps#cbn-news), developed by our parent company, to stay up-to-date with the latest news from a distinctly Christian perspective.***

author: Ground News
title: Ground News - Navalny's penal colony in the Arctic is direct heir to Russia's Gulag
text:
Summary by Ground News Jailed Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny has been transferred to a penal colony north of the Arctic Circle. The IK-3 penal colony, located in Kharp in the Yamalo-Nenets region, is considered to be one of the toughest prisons in Russia. Penal colonies are descendants of Soviet-era Gulags, the notorious Stalin-era labour camps where thousands of Russians lost their lives. Share menu More

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Fatal familial insomnia: a genetic condition where people never sleep again
text:
By Emily Cooke ,
11 hours ago
Disease name: Fatal familial insomnia (FFI)
Affected populations: The disease affects an estimated 1 to 2 people per million every year , according to the National Organization of Rare Disorders. FFI is passed from parent to child, and between 50 and 70 families worldwide are believed to carry the genetic mutation that causes FFI. Males and females are equally likely to develop the condition.
Causes: FFI is a neurodegenerative prion disease that is caused by a mutation in a gene called PRNP , which produces a so-called prion protein. Prions are misfolded versions of normal proteins, and their abnormal shape is toxic to cells in the body, particularly neurons in the brain . One of the tissues that is primarily damaged in patients with FFI is the thalamus , a region of the brain that regulates an array of body functions including sleep, body temperature and appetite.
Children need to inherit only one copy of the mutant PRNP gene from a parent to develop the condition. In rare instances, patients may spontaneously develop mutations in the PRNP gene, despite having no family history of FFI. They can then pass this mutation on to their children in the regular way.
Related: Not all insomnia is the same â€” in fact, there may be 5 types
Symptoms: The hallmark symptom of FFI is insomnia, or the inability to fall or stay asleep , which progressively worsens over time to the point where patients cannot sleep at all .
Patients with FFI also commonly experience memory loss, high blood pressure, hallucinations and involuntary jerking of their muscles . They may sweat profusely and lose their coordination .
Symptoms usually begin around age 40, but can develop as early as age 20 or as late as age 70. Patients eventually enter a coma-like state and typically die within nine to 30 months after their symptoms emerge.
Brain scans of a patient with fatal familial insomnia. (Image credit: Tingting Lu, Yuhang Pan, Lisheng Peng, Feng Qin, Xiaobo Sun, Zhengqi Lu, and Wei Qiu; Fatal familial insomnia with abnormal signals on routine MRI: a case report and literature review. BMC Neurol. 2017 May 26;17(1):104. doi: 10.1186/s12883-017-0886-2, CC BY 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en , via Wikimedia Commons) Treatments: There is currently no cure for FFI . As the disease is so rare, there is also no standard way of treating it. Instead, patients may be given advice on how to best manage their symptoms and live as comfortable a life as possible . For instance, taking the drug clonazepam can reduce muscle jerking .
â€” 'Love hormone' oxytocin may be missing link between sleep apnea and high blood pressure
â€” What is sleep hygiene?
â€” Is insomnia a sign of pregnancy?
A medical case report from 2006 showed that trying to induce sleep â€” for instance, by engaging in rigorous exercise and taking narcoleptic drugs â€” extended and enhanced the life of 52-year-old man with FFI by about a year, but did not prevent his death .
In 2015, a clinical trial of a drug that aims to prevent the onset of FFI was launched. Over 10 years, 10 people who carry the FFI mutation will be given the antibiotic doxycycline and their prognosis and survival after disease onset will be compared to patients who previously died of FFI. Doxycycline has also been shown to prevent the formation of misfolded proteins in another prion disease, called Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, helping patients live twice as long as those who didn't receive the treatment .
Ever wonder why some people build muscle more easily than others or why freckles come out in the sun ? Send us your questions about how the human body works to community@livescience.com with the subject line "Health Desk Q," and you may see your question answered on the website!
5
